values: Since graduation I have found myself with a dearth of time on my hands, which has lead to a great deal of introspection and reflection (though not the standard emo variety to which I have become accustom) and it has lead me down a road of renewal and rebirth, a personal renaissance if you will, regarding how I view myself, the world, and the way things work. Before I can say goodbye to the Henry of yesteryear completely, however, there are still a few outstanding items I'd like to address in the skeleton-filled closet that is my past. These particular skeletons take the form of 'the three Gs' which I have found myself consumed by as of late. Graduation: It went remarkably well. I didn't have a panic attack or embarrass myself or anything. I truly felt changed as I grasped my diploma, not dissimilar to how children grasp their favorite toy or blanket, the actual object itself not so important, but its symbolism of security and understanding comforting and validating all on its own. I have stepped through the doorway to adulthood, not as reluctantly as I thought I might have, and I must admit, I have found myself pleasantly surprised with the freedom (and even the restraint and responsibility) that has awaited me on the other side. Like seeing an old friend after a lengthy absence, I am reminded of a time when things were much simpler and I spent my time worry-free, basking in the warm, loving glow of my family and loved ones, occupying my time with the trivial activities I so loved. I do not know how long this transitional period will last, but I do know I will love every minute of my existence while I am in it, and harbor no further regrets. Speaking of regrets... Girls: My high school romantic experiences have been turbulent and sporadic, occurring less frequently over time, and then in rapid succession, only to be further spaced out by drought. I would like to send some last words to all the girls I have wronged/been wronged by over these past four years, though most of them will likely never hear these words: Mackenzie- I am so sorry for everything that has ever happened between us. I am so sorry you had to be the girl I learned how to love from. I fucked so much shit up between us because I was young and stupid, and every time I see you I silently pray for your present and future happiness. There is no ill will between us, at least on my end. Go into the world and be what you have always meant to be. Goodbye and good luck. Nicole- I always have and always will love you. You are never far from my thoughts, and to this day I entertain fantasies of what we would be like if we were still together. It is sick, and obsessive that after 2 years I still cannot let you go, but I have never been as happy, before or since I was with you. I may never know that happiness again, but I am thankful I was given what little time we had, because from you I learned truly what love is and I will never have to worry about never having experienced something as pure or as a beautiful as what we had. You deserve so much happiness that I know I could never do you justice. Though time and distance may separate us now, you will always remain near in my heart. Chelssy- You met me at a very weird time in my life. I'm so sorry I roped you into my paranoid delusion that unless I found someone right then and there who could look at me with hungry eyes, the way only you can seem to, that I was worthless. I tried to use you to validate me and once I realized that was selfish, I became despondent until you left me. It was the right decision to make and it shows how strong a person you are; you know what you deserve, you know what you want, and how to get it. Never lose sight of these things and you will go far in life. You are the only person on this list I honestly think I don't have to worry about for the future; you will do just fine, wherever you go. Mallory- You made the unfortunate mistake of being nice to me, not knowing I have a tendency to fall in love with every girl who shows me the slightest bit of attention. You are an amazing person who deserves someone equally amazing and I am so sorry I tried to cheapen our relationship with messy, shallow, meaningless, physical entanglements. It was a weak point in my life and I am eternally ashamed of how I acted around you. Please forgive me, I was lonely and alienated from the world around me. The kindness and warmth you showed to me meant more to me then then you will ever know. Brittany- You are forever my enigma wrapped in a conundrum. Quite possibly, you are the girl in my high school life I will look back on with the greatest fondness. I will never forget that shining night in early Decemeber at Chelssy's house when you looked into my eyes, kissed me, and told me that I was beautiful. That single utterance has meant more to me than anything else anyone has ever said to me in my entire life. You were kind to me, you loved me, you let me love you, and then...you shunned me. And I will never know why. But some things are better left unknown. You are my single, biggest regret, because you are the most perfect girl that I have ever met, and the knowledge that I am not a strong enough human being to tame you still burns in the periphery of my conscious mind. Theresa- You once told me you couldn't believe I loved you if you thought you could have just been 'any other girl'. I didn't fully grok those words until just this moment, but it perfectly encapsulates our predicament. I DID love you. I loved you wholly and completely. I defied all odds and rational thought and intensely loved every inch of you. Every time I kissed you, I felt something so amazing and so right that I couldn't ever bear to know that perhaps, just perhaps, THIS would be the last time. So where did things go wrong? You didn't love me. I was just 'another guy'. One more uninteresting, soulless husk of a man who threw himself into your path. How could you have done anything besides walk all over me? All because I didn't play the guitar, I didn't drink and get high every weekend, because I truly understood and accepted every dark, gothic corner of your being. But that's not what you're looking for. You're looking for someone you can hide from. Someone you can lie to. Someone you can pretend with. But I'd never let you pretend. You couldn't ever lie to me. I hope someday you're ready for a real, adult relationship with someone, and I hope you find someone special to share that with. I think you'll find, once you give it a try, that it's actually much more fulfilling. Wow, that felt amazing. 4 years worth of sadness and pent up emotions, vomitted up, violently into a few paragraphs of incoherent babble... Grief: I could not have felt less attached to my high school. I always thought that there was something wrong with me, because I didn't like any of the people I knew. I found them all flat, static, two dimensional. No one seemed good enough for me. I used to think that was because I was fucked up and hyper-critical. But I realize now that I was just resisting the conformity that all youths have to go through in high school; find a clique, or be alone. I didn't think I could spend 4 years in complete social solitude, but by god I did it, and I emerged more or less unscathed. I will now enter the real world and find newer and more interesting people and form bonds with them that will be so rewarding and fulfilling I'll wonder why I ever even wasted the neurons processing the presence of some of the people I knew in high school. Meanwhile, they will continue to live their high school lives, over and over, ad nauseum until they awake one fateful day to realize they are 30 and still acting like they are 18. That will be a rude awakening, to be sure. That is all. I am so happy with who I am and where I am right now that I can't even imagine some of the despair that is chronicled in this journal. Next week, I will be getting my license to drive my new car (which I absolutely adore), Colin and I will begin our apartment hunt, and then life as an adult will truly begin. I cannot wait. This will be the last time I ever pen any words into this journal. It has served well for its purpose; that is, chronicling the hapless misadventures of a disaffected, disillusioned, emo high school student, but that time has passed. It is full of too many bad memories and shattered dreams that even staring at its front page sends chills up my spine. This is not who I am anymore, and it seems so disfigured to me now that I cannot even recognize what morbid, self-hating corner of my brain it was born from. I will leave this journal up until the very bits on the hard drive it is stored on has decayed and rotten due to the ravages of time, with the hope that perhaps someday some one else, perhaps a similarly maligned young child, will happen upon it and find that no matter how detached from the world around them they feel, they are never truly alone. Perhaps someday, some lonely night down the road it will occur to me to start a new live journal, to start a new chapter in my life, but this chapter, like all, must ultimately have an ending. A point of no return; a point of completion, though the reader must be content in the knowledge that what they have just read can never, EVER, be unread. This is that point. Goodbye, high school. You were the worst thing that ever happened to me.

As you may have surmised from my previous entry I've begun to immerse myself in the field of discovery and self-betterment that is neurolingusitic programming and several other schools of analysis regarding social dynamics (particularlly relating to male/female relationships vis-a-vis courting, attraction, love, etc) and all I can say is...wow. I've never felt such clarity and understanding of the world and the way people work as I do right now. Learning about communication is so vital to understanding it and making work for you and with you.

Part of the ASF seduction manuscript I've been reading has been about improving yourself by establishing a strong frame or mental window through which we percieve the world and learning how to demonstate value to other people by having a strong emotional center and learning to draw interest from others by achieving congruence between the way you are and the way you act around others. It's truly a mind-blowing experience to be actively engaging in activities and behaviors which increase your self-esteem and sense of worth and entitlement, and at the same time allow others to see that within you as well.

I'm trying to take it one step at a time, right now focusing on how to not be 'reactive' regarding male/female relationships. Realizing that I am in control of my own emotions and feelings and I am an inherently useful human being of worth, regardless of how other people (specifically objects of romantic desire) feel about me or act around me is an immensely rewarding feeling and I no longer feel drawn to find 'completeness' within others. I am whole and perfect in and of myself. We all are.

Here are a few things I've learned in my journey to self-betterment so far, and it may behoove you to examine these principles and see if you can draw anything from them:

- The ability to change the process by which we experience reality is more often valuable than changing the content of our experience of reality. 

- The map is not the territory.

- People already have all the resources they need.

- Life and 'Mind' are systemic processes.

- Underlying structure matters more than specific content.

- Behind every behavior is a positive intention.

- There is no failure, only feedback.

- The meaning of your communication is the response you get.

Applying these sorts of principles and axioms to my every day life will be tricky sure, but for the first time in a long while I feel confident that I can evoke a change in my own life. It is a truly magical feelings.

Let's see how my first attempt at life-narration goes, keeping all these things in mind, and with me acting out of a desire to demonstrate high value.

~*~

It all comes back to Theresa. She has been the focal point of my life for the past few months, in a very big, self-destructive way. I have put myself in this position because of my lack of self-worth and allowed these terrible events to unfold around me and then claim ignorance when my actions of consequences.

That said, truly, the way I feel about her has not changed one iota. I simply percieve the situation and our actions, differently.

She has 2 months left in this town, a 2 month window to decide whether or not I am worth the trouble of acknowledging my 'romantic elligiblity', if you will. I've tried everything that I thought I knew to demonstate high value to her. I showed her jerkiness, indifference, compassion, neglience, sweetness, thoughtfulness, everything I thought might get me what I wanted. The problem that has arisen is that most of those things are alright, and may very well have worked out for me, if only I had been congruent about it. She's seen so many faces, she can't possibly be expected to know which ones were real, which ones were defense mechanisms, which ones were elaborate lies meant to decieve and mislead.

So what am I going to do?

Absolutely nothing. She know where I stand, I have communicated my feelings for her in almost every way I know how. It is up to her to act on it now.

Before my journey towards 'proactivity' began I found myself very hurt that she was not giving me more of her precious little time. That somehow she owed me her attention because I NEEDED it. I see now that that is completely faulty. Being needy is what has gotten me into this mess. I will not burden her, or anyone else, with that any longer. I am going to keep on living, keep on moving forward with my life, and if she would like to include me in her last days here in Portland, I would be delighted to take part in that, and if she is too busy soaking in the people around her, hastily trying to have experiences she can hang on to while she lives her life in what she views as social alcatraz, then that is only human, and I cannot fault her for that.

But if not, then I have my answer, in a not particularlly messy way, and we can both move on. Either way, the situation is resolved, everyone has what they need to continue living, and at least on my end, there will be no hard feelings.

Even if I have not captured her heart, I have not failed in this experience. For after all, there is no failure...only feedback.

I'm getting some good, clear thinking done lately. It's great stuff and makes me wonder how I can ever view things as obsufcatedly as they seem to be some times.

The question I've been pondering today: why do I consistently go after the same types of women when it only ever ends in heartbreak, tragedy, and alienation?

There is something in me that likes to be a 'fixer'. Something of a 'knight in shining armor' complex that drives me to seek out...how do I put this delicately...non-traditional women, who have lived non-traditional lives (hey that wasn't half bad) and try to save them from, well...often, as it turns out, save them from themselves.

Part of it is, I guess, that I like to be the normal one in the relationship. These kind of relationships tend to be trickier to maintain, due to the finickiness of both parties involved, and have the appearance of being 'more interesting' than more normal, traditional ones, which, on its face, also tends to seem more appealing, as easily bored as I am.

But this seems at odds with other core values that I have; the belief that I am a human being of immense worth and deserve nothing less than exactly what I desire in a partner. Maybe I've just watched one too many bad high school teen drama movies where 2 amazing people collide and they find exactly what they were looking for, but I've always felt that at some point I will find that as well.

There is some sort of bizarre cognitive dissonance that exists between my desire for romantic intimacy of any kind (emotional or sexual) and my perfectionist, obsessive inability to accept anything less than absolute perfection.

So how do I reconcile that? In reflection, I've noticed that I tend to exaggerate the positive and undermine (and even sometimes blatantly ignore) the negative in whoever I am into at the time.

I'm feeling the same sort of disturbing revulsion that I felt when I got out of my relationship with Chelssy. That whole sort of 'what the FUCK was I thinking?' sense of failure and self-delusion. When you re-examine a person post-relationship and re-evaluate their qualities, there is bound to be some anger-induced bias/disparity in the perception between what you see now and what you thought you saw, but I am consistently overwhelmed with just HOW vast the disparity often is.

In retrospect, it seems almost TOO obvious. How could I have ignored so much in a vain attempt to gain so little?

Everyone told me 'dude, don't go there'. I ignored them. I told them they didn't know her like I did. I thought they were just jealous. They didn't want me to be happy.

Then she told me 'I can't believe you want to go there'. And what did I say? 'I don't care. It's not important. It is insignificant to the scope of these proceedings'. 

But it ISN'T. To say that how someone has acted in the past, how they are acting now, and how they will act in the future aren't at all related is just self-delusion in its purest form.

I really am the eternal optimist, despite my reputation. I give everyone I care about the benefit of the doubt, often at my peril, because of my belief in the power of love, as corny and completely out of character as it sounds.

There are so many things that seemed so small and insignificant at the time that I thought I could just let go, but they all stacked up, collapsed, and caught me in the undertow.

Maybe I need to reassess what I want in a partner. Try to figure out how to keep this sort of ridiculous bullshit from happening anymore.

Welp, I've got nothing but time. What DO I really want in a woman?

- Someone who understands and loves me for who I am
- Someone who I understand and I love for who they are
- Strong emotional connection between two dynamic people
- Intellectual and social stimulation

A moment of clarity. I love it when these just strike me. I REALLY have to hold on to this one too. High School is almost over. 17 more days of turbulent adolescent melodrama, and then I am forcibly ejected into the real world. And you know, for the first time, I'm excited about this. I'm going to enter a completely new echelon of romantic experience. I'm going to meet new women and I'm going to actually have to COURT them. No more of this 'harboring silent love for them for an extended period of time and then exploding on them'. Because it isn't fair. It's all I've ever done. I hate to get all 'ladder theory all women are whores' about this, but I think a lot of it is pretty accurate, at least in a high school context. All I've ever done is climb to the tippy top of the friend ladder and hurl myself with reckless abandon across the abyss. Sometimes it works...sort of. Usually I'll fall short and just barely cling to the last rung. But that's something to me. I'll shout and be jubliant and exclaim 'I DID IT! I FUCKING DID IT! I MADE IT!' even as my pinky grasp slips and I begin to plummet. All the way down I am too destracted with my 'success' to even notice my impending doom. And then when I DO hit bottom all I can do is go, 'fuck. didn't see that one coming'. But no more. I'm going to have to APPROACH women and ASK them out on dates and COURT them, in the traditional sense that I have evaded for so long. It's always been scary to me. But it's so much more ethical than what I've been doing. It wasn't right for me to tell Theresa how I feel. I ruined our friendship, for what? Some fleeting comfort that no longer having to carry a burden (that I am solely responsible for its creation) brings. And what did I expect? I don't really have a witty intro to segue into my thoughts today. Nor an amalgam of poorly formated pseudo-poetry. It is, what it is I guess.

I WILL preface this entry, however, with some self-deprecation. An admission of humanity, if you will.

I have emotional and mental issues. Whether they are simply bothersome little neuroses or are the tragic effects of some neurological chemical imbalance, I cannot say for certain. I have staggering self-esteem issues which make me risk-averse the point of never trying anything or having any goals. I have fears of failure and rejection, both in my private, and romantic social life. I have crippling emotional problems which has lead to become unable to form any meaningful long term interpersonal relationships. I have problems with self-entitlement insofar as I am uncertain when bad things happen to me whether or not I should blame myself, and when good things happen, I feel undeserving of them. I act as though everything I have is worth nothing, and then it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy. I have recently come to realize that I have commitment issues. Not necessarily in a romantic pretext, but I find myself constantly having one foot out the door, ready to leave or be left, because of my cynical notions of time and the way world works, being perpetually prepared to have to start over with nothing.

I see all these things. I am trying to work on them.

ALL THAT BEING SAID, I think I'm doing better. I'm going after more things that I want. I'm trying riskier things. I'm becoming more uncomfortable with emotional uncertainty. I think the few friendships I have maintained through out the course of high school are stronger than they ever were. I am happy with my progress back to normalcy.

Normally, this is all I ever have to deal with. My own emotionally fragile, immensely complicated and neurotic brain functions. But things are different now. I have found someone else just like me. And I like them. A lot.

While this seems as though it is coming right out of a terrible FOX sitcom, it's true. My vision is beginning to become unclouded, and I'm beginning to perceive Theresa as having similar problems as I do.

Since 'the spring break massacre' as I have taken to endearingly refer to the incident and the following 'black monday', things have been tenuous and up in the air between us. Okay, we both have feelings for each other. We find each other at least sexually attractive enough to kiss. She sometimes was very intimate with me, emotionally and proximity-wise, other times, more distant and aloof. Sometimes she seems to despise her boyfriend, other time she seems to claim not to be able to live with out him. A natural balance of sorts, if I may hearken back to a previous LJ entry.

A sense of helplessness gripped me wholly for a time. The prize was within reach. I had said most of the right things and gone through most of the right motions and I was rewarded accordingly. But could I have my cake and eat it too?

I didn't know what to do. Before, in my earlier conundrums I could at least identify the choices and struggle over which one was the right one, but now I am blank. I have no idea what I can do to influence the situation. I know there is probably the one magical word that no one has heard before, that if it escaped my lips in the right tone, at the right time, in the right place, I could salvage this whole mess. I knew that. But what would that word be? How could I discover it?

It was troubling, leaving your romantic fate in the hands of a teenage girl. I never put myself on the line like this. So why now? What made this worth the terror and agony of waiting and wondering and doubting and crying?

The waiting game is the worst game of all, because no one really wins. If you have to wait for something, you're not going to get it. To play the game is to lose it. I moved quickly from helplessness to dispair.

Time flowed as it always does. Nothing really changed. Nothing concrete. Fragments of eternity here and there, but nothing to act as a foundation for a mature, rewarding relationship. "It will come," I told myself, "This too shall pass."

Pass it did. No longer am I uncertain as to how she feels. I have it almost nailed down to a tee (i think).

Today, I had lunch with Theresa. It was a veritable emotional roller coaster.

We went to buy our prom tickets. It was fine, it felt good for both of us I think to get one more thing on the big ol' checklist-o-shit to do before prom comes done. We walk to QFC in the rain. I always like the rain. Everything seems so much more beautiful when it's wet to me, I'm not sure why.

Even her.

We split up in the grocery store. We like different things. I pay first, and wait outside for her. A few minutes pass. My stomach does the cold, churning thing. Is it a panic attack?

I get those sometimes. Usually only under extremely stressful situations. I've had 3 to date. Once before I lost my virginity, the second time when I was going to be late to final exams one school year because my bus broke down, and the third right before the SATs.

I don't know what panic attacks are like for other people, but for me they are absolutely terrifying. It starts first with the cold, churning stomach. Then your heart begins to beat faster and faster as worrying thoughts begin to fill your head. My face flushes beat red. I begin to sweat. But it is...cold. Cold sweat. My pupils dilate and my ability to perceive colors is sapped. Only amalgams of black and purple. Then I faint. And it's over as quickly as it started.

But why have a panic attack here? Outside a QFC? Theresa has only been in there a few minutes. What the hell is wrong with me?

But I never make the jump to stage two. The cold sweat never comes. Just a pervading sense of anxiety and animosity grips me. 

I watch Mr. Alvord, a teacher at Grant, pull up in his car and park in the handicap spot while he runs in and grabs something. His immaturity and irresponsiblity have always angered me. I make a silent vow to get his car towed. I will never follow through with it.

Moments later Theresa exits, and feigns an apology. The feeling doesn't subside. I resolve to forget about it. I comment on Mr. Alvord's behavior and make light of it to change the mood.

I fail.

I am assaulted with a diatribe about how I don't 'really know' Mr. Alvord. The implication being, I suppose, that I am too judgmental and condescending. I'm pretty sure he just parked in a handicap space, though. But what do I know.

It came out of left field. I stumble over my words trying to erect a defense for an attack I never could have seen coming.

"Stop arguing with me!" She shouts.

And...just let you win? That isn't my style. I pull no punches. But I am too dumbfounded to even process the events unfolding around me. I stick to silence. Silence is golden. Silence is safe. Better to be silent and be thought a fool, than to speak and leave no doubt.

She seems to slowly become cognizant of her hasty behavior. She constructs something resembling an apology, but it's really more like an excuse. She's had a bad couple days. Why? She's been getting high at lunch and then skipping her classes because she's too fucked up to think straight.

I hate pot, for the record. I broke down and tried it once over spring break, and now I can say with first hand experience, pot is by the far the dumbest thing you can spend your time doing. I hate hanging out with people that are high. I hate it even more when people bitch about how doing it fucks with them. Just an exercise in retarded adolescent futility.

A months worth of bitter anger leaks out in a single venom-laced admission.

"I'm sorry you're having a bad day, but you kind of did it to yourself, so forgive me not being entirely sympathetic."

And that was the last we spoke today. Silence, all the way back to school, except for the beautiful Portland rain.

~*~

It has been hard for me to deal with the mixed messages and conflicting emotions both within her and within myself. She has been pushing me away all week, and I'm not entirely sure what I've done wrong, except perhaps be a bit snippy here and there, but I feel I'm entitled to that much at least.

There's the part of me, watching all I've worked for crumbling down around me, that wants to frantically reach out and grasp the peices as they fall. Call her. Apologize. Do some more nice things for her without being recognized. Whatever.

But then there's the other part that is beginning to suspect something more dire. Maybe she isn't pushing me away because she's scared or she doesn't know how to tell me no, or she has decided that I'm not the kind of guy she wants to be with or whatever. I pray it is one of those things because acting shitty to person when you feel that way is an ENTIRELY HUMAN RESPONSE and I could identify with that and I could understand and I could forgive or ignore or tolerate or whatever I'd have to do to not let this bother me.

Maybe she's finally snapped, the way I always worried I would. And she will kick and push and scream and drive me away to make sure our beautiful work of art never sees the light of day.

If this is the case, what can I do? I am powerless in every sense of the word. There is no one magic word to fix a chemical imbalance. I am completely at the mercy of her and my neuroses. I can pray they will work together and we will emerge through the crucible unscathed.
